sn7.2:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn7.2:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn7.2:1.2.eng: The brahmin Bhāradvāja the Rude heard a rumor that

sn7.2:2.1.pli: “bhāradvājagotto kira brāhmaṇo samaṇassa gotamassa santike agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito”ti kupito anattamano yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ asabbhāhi pharusāhi vācāhi akkosati paribhāsati. Evaṃ vutte, bhagavā akkosakabhāradvājaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.2:2.1.eng: a brahmin of the Bhāradvāja clan had gone forth from the lay life to homelessness in the presence of the ascetic Gotama. Angry and displeased he went to the Buddha and abused and insulted him with rude, harsh words. When he had spoken, the Buddha said to him:
sn7.2:2.1.comm: Apparently a reference to the previous Sutta.

sn7.2:2.3.pli: api nu kho te āgacchanti mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā atithiyo”ti?
sn7.2:2.3.eng: Do friends and colleagues, relatives and kin, and guests still come to visit you?”

sn7.2:2.4.pli: “Appekadā me, bho gotama, āgacchanti mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā atithiyo”ti.

sn7.2:2.5.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, brāhmaṇa, api nu tesaṃ anuppadesi khādanīyaṃ vā bhojanīyaṃ vā sāyanīyaṃ vā”ti?
sn7.2:2.5.eng: “Do you then serve them with fresh and cooked foods and savories?”

sn7.2:2.6.pli: “Appekadā nesāhaṃ, bho gotama, anuppademi khādanīyaṃ vā bhojanīyaṃ vā sāyanīyaṃ vā”ti.

sn7.2:2.7.pli: “Sace kho pana te, brāhmaṇa, nappaṭiggaṇhanti, kassa taṃ hotī”ti?
sn7.2:2.7.eng: “But if they don’t accept it, brahmin, who does it belong to?”

sn7.2:2.8.pli: “Sace te, bho gotama, nappaṭiggaṇhanti, amhākameva taṃ hotī”ti.
sn7.2:2.8.eng: “In that case it still belongs to me.”

sn7.2:2.9.pli: “Evameva kho, brāhmaṇa, yaṃ tvaṃ amhe anakkosante akkosasi, arosente rosesi, abhaṇḍante bhaṇḍasi, taṃ te mayaṃ nappaṭiggaṇhāma.
sn7.2:2.9.eng: “In the same way, brahmin, when you abuse, harass, and attack us who do not abuse, harass, and attack, we don’t accept it.

sn7.2:2.10.eng: It still belongs to you, brahmin,

sn7.2:3.1.pli: Yo kho, brāhmaṇa, akkosantaṃ paccakkosati, rosentaṃ paṭiroseti, bhaṇḍantaṃ paṭibhaṇḍati, ayaṃ vuccati, brāhmaṇa, sambhuñjati vītiharatīti.
sn7.2:3.1.eng: Someone who, when abused, harassed, and attacked, abuses, harasses, and attacks in return is said to eat the food and have a reaction to it.

sn7.2:3.2.pli: Te mayaṃ tayā neva sambhuñjāma na vītiharāma.
sn7.2:3.2.eng: But we neither eat your food nor do we have a reaction to it.

sn7.2:3.3.eng: It still belongs to you, brahmin,

sn7.2:3.5.pli: “Bhavantaṃ kho gotamaṃ sarājikā parisā evaṃ jānāti:
sn7.2:3.5.eng: “The king and his retinue believe of the worthy Gotama,

sn7.2:3.6.eng: ‘the ascetic Gotama is a perfected one’.

sn7.2:3.7.pli: Atha ca pana bhavaṃ gotamo kujjhatī”ti.
sn7.2:3.7.eng: And yet he still gets angry.”

sn7.2:4.1.eng: “Whence anger for one free of anger,

sn7.2:5.1.eng: When you get angry at an angry person

sn7.2:5.2.eng: you just make things worse for yourself.

sn7.2:5.3.eng: When you don’t get angry at an angry person

sn7.2:5.4.eng: you win a battle hard to win.

sn7.2:6.1.eng: When you know that the other is angry,

sn7.2:6.2.eng: you act for the good of both

sn7.2:6.4.eng: if you’re mindful and stay calm.

sn7.2:7.1.comm: Read ubhinnaṁ tikicchantaṁ taṁ per Thag 6.12:4.1.

sn7.2:8.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, akkosakabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.2:8.1.eng: When he had spoken, Bhāradvāja the Rude said to the Buddha,

sn7.2:8.3.pli: esāhaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
sn7.2:8.3.eng: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

sn7.2:8.4.pli: Labheyyāhaṃ, bhante, bhoto gotamassa santike pabbajjaṃ, labheyyaṃ upasampadan”ti.
sn7.2:8.4.eng: Sir, may I receive the going forth, the ordination in the worthy Gotama’s presence?”

sn7.2:9.1.pli: Alattha kho akkosakabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ, alattha upasampadaṃ.
sn7.2:9.1.eng: And the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Rude received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.

sn7.2:9.2.pli: Acirūpasampanno kho panāyasmā akkosakabhāradvājo eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
sn7.2:9.2.eng: Not long after his ordination, Venerable Bhāradvāja the Rude, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

sn7.2:9.3.pli: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
sn7.2:9.3.eng: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”

sn7.2:9.4.pli: Aññataro ca panāyasmā bhāradvājo arahataṃ ahosīti.
sn7.2:9.4.eng: And Venerable Bhāradvāja became one of the perfected.
sn7.2:9.4.comm: He is no longer called “the Rude”.

sn7.20:1.2.pli: Atha kho bhikkhako brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn7.20:1.2.eng: Then a brahmin almsman went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

sn7.20:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho bhikkhako brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.20:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha,

sn7.20:1.4.pli: “ahampi kho, bho gotama, bhikkhako, bhavampi bhikkhako, idha no kiṃ nānākaraṇan”ti?
sn7.20:1.4.eng: “Worthy Gotama, both you and I are almsmen. What, then, is the difference between us?”
sn7.20:1.4.comm: “Almsman” (bhikkhaka) is almost identical with the standard word for a Buddhist mendicant (bhikkhu), but typically it is used of  almsgoing brahmins (eg. Manu 3.243).

sn7.20:2.2.eng: just by begging alms from others.

sn7.20:2.3.eng: One who has undertaken domestic duties
sn7.20:2.3.comm: The Sanskrit parallel at Uv 32:18 read veśmāṁ dharmaṁ, confirming that vissa here means “domestic”.

sn7.20:2.4.eng: has not yet become a mendicant.

sn7.20:3.1.eng: But one living a spiritual life

sn7.20:3.2.eng: who has banished both merit and evil,

sn7.20:3.3.eng: and wanders having appraised the world,

sn7.20:3.4.eng: is said to be a mendicant.”

sn7.20:4.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhikkhako brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.20:4.1.eng: When he had spoken, the brahmin almsman said to the Buddha,

sn7.20:4.3.pli: upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
sn7.20:4.3.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

sn7.21:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena saṅgāravo nāma brāhmaṇo sāvatthiyaṃ paṭivasati udakasuddhiko, udakena parisuddhiṃ pacceti, sāyaṃ pātaṃ udakorohanānuyogamanuyutto viharati.
sn7.21:1.2.eng: Now at that time there was a brahmin named Saṅgārava staying in Sāvatthī. He practiced purification by water, believing in purification by water. He lived committed to the practice of immersing himself in water at daybreak and dusk.
sn7.21:1.2.comm: A Saṅgārava of Sāvatthī appears in a number of discourses, and his spiritual progression can be traced. Here he practices purification in water, and (apparently later) asked the Buddha about sacrifice (AN 3.60). He further asked how hymns are remembered (SN 46.55, AN 5.193). In all these discourses he was said to have gone for refuge at the end. Finally he asks the more meaningful spiritual question about the near shore and far shore (AN 10.117, AN 10.169). It is possible that the teenage “student” (māṇava) Saṅgārava living at Caṇḍalakappa (MN 100) graduated and moved to nearby Sāvatthī where he became known as the “brahmin” Saṅgārava. This would only make sense, however, if we disregard the statements on going for refuge, as he clearly followed the Brahmanical path for quite some time.

sn7.21:1.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
sn7.21:1.3.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.

sn7.21:1.4.pli: Sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.21:1.4.eng: He wandered for alms in Sāvatthī. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

sn7.21:1.5.pli: “idha, bhante, saṅgāravo nāma brāhmaṇo sāvatthiyaṃ paṭivasati udakasuddhiko, udakena suddhiṃ pacceti, sāyaṃ pātaṃ udakorohanānuyogamanuyutto viharati.
sn7.21:1.5.eng: “Sir, there is a brahmin named Saṅgārava staying in Sāvatthī. He practices purification by water, believing in purification by water. He lives devoted to ritual bathing at daybreak and dusk.

sn7.21:1.6.pli: Sādhu, bhante, bhagavā yena saṅgāravassa brāhmaṇassa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā”ti.
sn7.21:1.6.eng: Please visit him at his home out of sympathy.”

sn7.21:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena saṅgāravassa brāhmaṇassa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
sn7.21:2.1.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the home of the brahmin Saṅgārava, and sat down on the seat spread out.

sn7.21:2.2.pli: Atha kho saṅgāravo brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn7.21:2.2.eng: Then the brahmin Saṅgārava went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

sn7.21:2.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho saṅgāravaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
sn7.21:2.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,

sn7.21:2.4.pli: “saccaṃ kira tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, udakasuddhiko, udakena suddhiṃ paccesi, sāyaṃ pātaṃ udakorohanānuyogamanuyutto viharasī”ti?
sn7.21:2.4.eng: “Is it really true, brahmin, that you practice purification by water, believing in purification by water; that you live committed to the practice of immersing yourself in water at daybreak and dusk?”

sn7.21:2.6.pli: “Kiṃ pana tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, atthavasaṃ sampassamāno udakasuddhiko, udakasuddhiṃ paccesi, sāyaṃ pātaṃ udakorohanānuyogamanuyutto viharasī”ti?
sn7.21:2.6.eng: “But brahmin, for what reason do you practice purification by water?”

sn7.21:2.7.pli: “Idha me, bho gotama, yaṃ divā pāpakammaṃ kataṃ hoti, taṃ sāyaṃ nhānena pavāhemi, yaṃ rattiṃ pāpakammaṃ kataṃ hoti taṃ pātaṃ nhānena pavāhemi.
sn7.21:2.7.eng: “It’s because, Mister Gotama, whatever bad deeds I’ve done during the day I rinse off by bathing at dusk; and whatever bad deeds I’ve done during the night, I rinse off by bathing at dawn.
sn7.21:2.7.comm: This quasi-physical understanding of good and evil predates the Buddha, and is found among Jains as well. The practice of ritual bathing is also listed among the self-mortifications, but it seems to fit better here, as bathing in India is not unpleasant (MN 12:45.12).

sn7.21:2.8.pli: Imaṃ khvāhaṃ, bho gotama, atthavasaṃ sampassamāno udakasuddhiko, udakena suddhiṃ paccemi, sāyaṃ pātaṃ udakorohanānuyogamanuyutto viharāmī”ti.
sn7.21:2.8.eng: That’s the reason why I practice purification by water.”

sn7.21:3.1.eng: “The teaching is a lake, brahmin, <j>into which ethics are the stairs,

sn7.21:3.2.eng: unclouded, praised by the fine to the good.

sn7.21:3.3.eng: There the knowledge masters go to bathe,

sn7.21:3.4.eng: and cross to the far shore with dry limbs.”

sn7.21:4.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, saṅgāravo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.21:4.1.eng: When he had spoken, Saṅgārava said to the Buddha,

sn7.21:4.3.pli: upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
sn7.21:4.3.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

sn7.22:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sakkesu viharati khomadussaṃ nāmaṃ sakyānaṃ nigamo.
sn7.22:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, where they have a town named Khomadussa.
sn7.22:1.2.comm: Khomadussa (“linen-cloth”) was probably named for the main product of the town. Flax for linen prefers temperate climes and is grown in northern India.

sn7.22:1.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya khomadussaṃ nigamaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
sn7.22:1.3.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Khomadussa for alms.

sn7.22:1.4.pli: Tena kho pana samayena khomadussakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā sabhāyaṃ sannipatitā honti kenacideva karaṇīyena, devo ca ekamekaṃ phusāyati.
sn7.22:1.4.eng: Now at that time the brahmins and householders of Khomadussa were gathered in the council hall for some business, while a gentle rain drizzled down.
sn7.22:1.4.comm: Brāhmaṇagahapatikā means “brahmins and householders” rather than “brahmin householders”. It is a term for the “landed gentry”. A householder is a landowner, not just a lay person. Council discussions were for the upper class, not the general populace (negamajānapadā).

sn7.22:1.5.pli: Atha kho bhagavā yena sā sabhā tenupasaṅkami.
sn7.22:1.5.eng: Then the Buddha approached that council.

sn7.22:1.6.pli: Addasaṃsu khomadussakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā bhagavantaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
sn7.22:1.6.eng: The brahmins and householders saw the Buddha coming off in the distance,

sn7.22:1.8.pli: “ke ca muṇḍakā samaṇakā, ke ca sabhādhammaṃ jānissantī”ti?
sn7.22:1.8.eng: “Who are these shavelings, these fake ascetics? Don’t they understand the council rules?”
sn7.22:1.8.comm: “Council rules” (sabhādhamma) appears only here. The Buddha plays with it, punning sabhā (“council”) with sabbhi (“the virtuous”), and dhamma (“rule”) with “principle, morality”. The text does not make clear what their problem was with the Buddha’s approach. If, as is usually understood, the rules of such councils were similar to the rules of the monastic code, the Council would be constituted of residents within the area, and once business was underway, it should not be interrupted.

sn7.22:1.9.pli: Atha kho bhagavā khomadussake brāhmaṇagahapatike gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn7.22:1.9.eng: Then the Buddha addressed the brahmins and householders of Khomadussa in verse:

sn7.22:2.1.eng: “If good people are not present it is no true council;

sn7.22:2.2.pli: Santo na te ye na vadanti dhammaṃ;
sn7.22:2.2.eng: and those whose speak against principle <j>are not good people.

sn7.22:2.3.eng: Having given up greed, hate, and delusion,

sn7.22:2.4.eng: speakers of principle are good people.”

sn7.22:3.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, khomadussakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn7.22:3.1.eng: When he had spoken, the brahmins and householders of Khomadussa said to the Buddha,

sn7.22:3.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
sn7.22:3.3.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.

sn7.22:3.4.pli: Ete mayaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāma dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
sn7.22:3.4.eng: We go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

sn7.22:3.5.pli: Upāsake no bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupete saraṇaṃ gate”ti.
sn7.22:3.5.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember us as lay followers who have gone for refuge for life.”

sn7.22:4.7.eng: The Linked Discourses with Brahmins are complete.

sn7.3:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn7.3:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn7.3:1.2.eng: The brahmin Bhāradvāja the Fiend heard a rumor to the effect that
sn7.3:1.2.comm: His name or epithet asurindaka (“demon-lord”) is sometimes used of Vṛtra, and hence is the exact opposite of what a brahmin should be.

sn7.3:1.3.pli: “bhāradvājagotto brāhmaṇo kira samaṇassa gotamassa santike agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito”ti kupito anattamano yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ asabbhāhi pharusāhi vācāhi akkosati paribhāsati.
sn7.3:1.3.eng: a brahmin of the Bhāradvāja clan had gone forth from the lay life to homelessness in the presence of the ascetic Gotama. Angry and displeased he went to the Buddha and abused and insulted him with rude, harsh words.

sn7.3:1.4.eng: But when he said this, the Buddha kept silent.

sn7.3:1.5.pli: Atha kho asurindakabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.3:1.5.eng: Then Bhāradvāja the Fiend said to the Buddha,

sn7.3:3.1.eng: When you get angry at an angry person

sn7.3:3.2.eng: you just make things worse for yourself.

sn7.3:3.3.eng: When you don’t get angry at an angry person

sn7.3:3.4.eng: you win a battle hard to win.

sn7.3:4.1.eng: When you know that the other is angry,

sn7.3:4.2.eng: you act for the good of both

sn7.3:4.4.eng: if you’re mindful and stay calm.

sn7.3:6.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, asurindakabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.3:6.1.eng: When he had spoken, Bhāradvāja the Fiend said to the Buddha,

sn7.3:6.4.pli: Aññataro ca panāyasmā bhāradvājo arahataṃ ahosīti.
sn7.3:6.4.eng: And Venerable Bhāradvāja became one of the perfected.

sn7.4:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn7.4:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn7.4:1.2.eng: The brahmin Bhāradvāja the Bitter heard a rumor that
sn7.4:1.2.comm: Bilaṅga (here, “bitter”) is allowed with other medicinal fruits at Kd 6:6.1.4. It is Sanskrit viḍaṅga, identified as embelia ribes or “false black pepper”. It is normally given as an example of poor food (SN 3.19:2.5).

sn7.4:1.3.pli: “bhāradvājagotto kira brāhmaṇo samaṇassa gotamassa santike agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito”ti kupito anattamano yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā tuṇhībhūto ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
sn7.4:1.3.eng: a brahmin of the Bhāradvāja clan had gone forth from the lay life to homelessness in the presence of the ascetic Gotama. Angry and displeased he went to the Buddha and stood silently to one side.
sn7.4:1.3.comm: The commentary says he was too angry to speak because his brothers, in the previous three discourses, had ordained.

sn7.4:1.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā bilaṅgikassa bhāradvājassa brāhmaṇassa cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya bilaṅgikaṃ bhāradvājaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn7.4:1.4.eng: Then the Buddha, knowing Bhāradvāja the Bitter’s train of thought, addressed him in verse:

sn7.4:2.1.eng: “Whoever wrongs a man who has done no wrong,

sn7.4:2.2.eng: a pure man who has not a blemish,

sn7.4:2.3.eng: the evil backfires on the fool,

sn7.4:3.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bilaṅgikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.4:3.1.eng: When he said this, the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Bitter said to the Buddha,

sn7.4:3.4.pli: Aññataro ca panāyasmā bhāradvājo arahataṃ ahosīti.
sn7.4:3.4.eng: And Venerable Bhāradvāja became one of the perfected.

sn7.5:1.2.pli: Atha kho ahiṃsakabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn7.5:1.2.eng: Then the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Harmless went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

sn7.5:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho ahiṃsakabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.5:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said,

sn7.5:1.4.eng: “I am Harmless, worthy Gotama, I am Harmless!”
sn7.5:1.4.comm: The name “harmless” (ahiṁsaka) was also given to Aṅgulimāla after his awakening (MN 86:18.35).

sn7.5:2.1.eng: “If you were really like your name,

sn7.5:2.4.eng: does no harm by way of

sn7.5:3.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, ahiṃsakabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.5:3.1.eng: When he had spoken, the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Harmless said to the Buddha,

sn7.5:3.4.pli: Aññataro ca panāyasmā ahiṃsakabhāradvājo arahataṃ ahosīti.
sn7.5:3.4.eng: And Venerable Bhāradvāja the Harmless became one of the perfected.

sn7.6:0.3.eng: With Bhāradvāja of the Matted Hair

sn7.6:1.2.pli: Atha kho jaṭābhāradvājo brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn7.6:1.2.eng: Then the brahmin Bhāradvāja of the Matted Hair went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

sn7.6:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
sn7.6:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,

sn7.6:1.4.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho jaṭābhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn7.6:1.4.eng: and addressed the Buddha in verse:

sn7.6:2.2.eng: these people are tangled in tangles.

sn7.6:4.1.eng: Those in whom greed, hate, and ignorance

sn7.6:4.3.eng: the perfected ones with defilements ended—

sn7.6:5.3.eng: as well as impingement and perception of form:

sn7.6:5.4.eng: it’s there that the tangle is cut.”

sn7.6:6.1.eng: When he had spoken, Bhāradvāja of the Matted Hair said to the Buddha,

sn7.6:6.3.pli: aññataro ca panāyasmā bhāradvājo arahataṃ ahosī”ti.
sn7.6:6.3.eng: And Venerable Bhāradvāja became one of the perfected.

sn7.7:1.2.pli: Atha kho suddhikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn7.7:1.2.eng: Then the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Pure went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

sn7.7:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
sn7.7:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,

sn7.7:1.4.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho suddhikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ ajjhabhāsi:
sn7.7:1.4.eng: and spoke this verse in his presence:

sn7.7:2.1.eng: “No brahmin in the world is ever purified

sn7.7:2.2.eng: even though he’s ethical and mortifies himself.

sn7.7:2.3.eng: But one accomplished in knowledge and conduct

sn7.7:2.4.pli: So sujjhati na aññā itarā pajā”ti.
sn7.7:2.4.eng: is purified, not these other commoners.”
sn7.7:2.4.comm: He betrays his prejudice in the last line.

sn7.7:3.3.eng: if they’re filthy and corrupt within,

sn7.7:4.1.eng: Regardless of whether you’re an aristocrat,

sn7.7:4.2.eng: a brahmin, peasant, menial, <j>or a corpse-worker or scavenger—

sn7.7:4.6.eng: Know that for a fact, brahmin.”

sn7.7:5.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, suddhikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.7:5.1.eng: When he had spoken, the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Pure said to the Buddha,

sn7.7:5.3.pli: aññataro ca panāyasmā bhāradvājo arahataṃ ahosīti.
sn7.7:5.3.eng: And Venerable Bhāradvāja became one of the perfected.
